data.text: Contents
Introduction

The main aim of this policy is to enhance the patient's surgical outcome by the maintenance of an aseptic environment within the operating theatre by promoting a standardised procedure for scrubbing; gowning and gloving based on current best practice and validated evidence.
Effective hand decontamination results in significant reductions in the numbers of potential pathogens on the hands and decreases the incidence of preventable healthcare associated infection.

The techniques employed by theatre personnel when preparing to take part in a sterile procedure may vary marginally, but they must adhere to the principles outlined in this policy which seek to reduce the risk of infection and maintain sterility.

Staff are encouraged to double glove by wearing a coloured glove puncture indicator system which enables the wearer to detect perforations in the outer glove more easily than wearing standard gloves. Double gloving provides an extra layer of protection and significantly reduces the number of perforations to inner gloves in all types of surgery. However the decision to double glove should be based on the risk posed by the surgical procedure (e.g. exposure to sharps) and not the risk posed by the patient, or personal preference. Evidence supports the use of double gloving for all surgical procedures. Latex free gloves must be available for individuals who are sensitised to latex proteins and / or other chemicals in the gloves. They must also be available for use by all scrub personnel when dealing with latex sensitive patients or those in a high risk category.
Purpose

This policy is aimed at all theatre staff within MSEFT group working across all theatres. No member of staff whatever designation will be allowed to take part in a sterile procedure until they have received instruction and been assessed as competent in the techniques of scrubbing, gowning and gloving by a designated assessor(s). (See appendix 1)
Definitions

table_items.text: Nurse/Operating Department Practitioner (ODP) who assists the surgeon/anaesthetist in the operating theatre
The nurse/ODP/HCA who assists the scrub practitioner in the operating theatre

data.text: Duties
Theatre, Critical Care and Anaesthetic Governance Committee is responsible for approving this policy
The Theatre Practice Group are responsible for the co-ordination, production, updating and monitoring of this policy.
The Chief Executive is ultimately responsible for ensuring that there are effective arrangements for infection prevention and control within the Trust.

The Trust Board are collectively responsible for minimising the risks from infection to patients, staff members and the public. They are responsible for the general means by which the Trust controls such infection risk
The Director of Infection Prevention and Control (DIPC) has executive responsibility to the Trust Board for infection prevention and control.

Clinical managers (consultants, managers, and clinical departmental managers) are responsible for ensuring that the work performed by the staff they are supervising is performed in accordance with this policy. This follows the usual lines of professional accountability.

Theatre Managers are responsible for their own theatres suites and must ensure that all members of staff adhere to this policy, thereby safeguarding patients. Managers of each operating theatre suite will ensure that staff adhere to this policy
Process

The fundamental principles of aseptic technique must be adhered to when scrubbing, gowning and gloving prior to a surgical intervention. Surgical scrub is an extension of hand washing and the six steps of hand washing should be used for surgical antisepsis and social hand wash. It is undertaken immediately prior to putting on sterile gowns and gloves before participating in surgical and invasive procedures. This is done in order to reduce the risk of cross infection in the event of glove perforations and to prevent the patients from developing surgical site infections.

Individual staff members can become allergic to some microbial scrub preparations; therefore alternative scrub solutions are available. In the event of using non-alcohol scrub solutions, the surgical scrub must be completed with an alcohol gel solution and allowed to dry as soap has no antimicrobial properties.

The purpose of the surgical scrub is to remove debris and transient micro- organisms, to reduce resident micro-organisms to a minimum and to inhibit rapid rebound growth on the hands, nails and forearms of surgical personnel. All staff must be in appropriate theatre attire before commencing a surgical scrub. The appropriate theatre attire consists of a scrub top and trousers, all hair must be covered fully by a theatre hat.

Shoes must be enclosed for personal protection and provide antistatic properties in compliance with EN 345, A, S1, S2 or S3.The use of overshoes is not recommended as these have shown to increase the floor bacterial counts as well as numbers of bacteria on the hands when the overshoes are applied or removed. The scrub practitioner must be aware that the purpose of the scrub procedure is to attack transient and resident micro-organisms on the hands and arms.
The technique for scrubbing and gowning is laid out in appendix 1

Training is competency based.

Appendix 1: Process for scrubbing, gowning and gloving

table_items.text: Staff will wear a new single use face mask correctly positioned over the nose and mouth and fitted comfortably Masks should be handled only by the ties If a headscarf is worn, it must be a clean headscarf and covered by a helmet style disposable theatre hat
Protects the patient from micro-organisms expelled from the mouth and naso pharynx of surgical staff during procedures, they also provide a protective barrier for the surgical team
Suitable face and eye protection that also covers the side of the face must be used by scrub personnel
To protect against splash injuries from blood and bodily fluids
All hair must be covered under a theatre hat
To prevent skin squames contaminating open wounds
Hands and nails must be clean with nails short and free from nail varnish. Gel nails are not acceptable
To minimise the risk of bacterial contamination
No jewellery must be worn except for a wedding ring and one pair of small, stud earrings
Spectacles and microscopic glasses must be securely positioned
To prevent falling into sterile field
If protective clothing is to be worn e.g. lead apron or plastic apron it must be worn under the sterile gown
All skin on hands and arms should be intact. Any cut or abrasion must be covered with a sterile waterproof dressing immediately prior to scrubbing and this dressing must be changed between cases
AT ALL TIMES THE STAFF MUST ENSURE THE FOLLOWING
The water must be of an even temperature and steady flow
In order to minimise contamination during scrubbing
Hands must be kept above the level of the elbows and away from theatre attire.
To allow water to flow from clean to dirty (hands to elbows) and to avoid contamination from splashing
Care must be taken not to splash theatre clothing
Rinsing must be performed from fingertips to elbow, using the water
flow. Hands must not be used for this purpose
Movements must remain steady. Vigorous shaking to dispel water from hands and arms is unacceptable

The scrub solution must be antiseptic or alcohol based. It must be fast acting and have a broad spectrum of action and a residual effect NB. Personnel who are allergic to scrub solutions can use soap, but must combine with an alcohol based solution/gel

Alcohol based solutions provide the most rapid and greatest reduction in microbial count, but are not effective at removing debris and soiling Soap and water alone are not acceptable, as soap has no antimicrobial properties
The scrub solution must stay intact with the skin
In order to attack transient and resident micro-organisms on the hands and arms
Approximately 5mls of scrub solution should be dispensed at each application and this must be worked into the hands and arms before washing off
Dispensing of copious amounts of scrub solution followed by quick application and rinsing is neither efficient in technique nor cost effective
The first wash must encompass the hands and arms to the elbows
Subsequent washes must not reach as far as the elbows. Two thirds of the forearm is an adequate level
This would compromise the effectiveness of the scrubbing technique

The six steps of hand washing must be incorporated into scrub: Palm to palm Right palm over left dorsum and left palm over right dorsum Palm to palm, fingers interlaced Backs of fingers to opposing palms with fingers interlocked Rotational rubbing of right thumb clasped in left palm and vice versa Rotational rubbing backwards and forwards with clasped fingers of right hand in left palm and vice versa.
For surgical antisepsis and social hand wash
A new single-use nail pick must be used for the first scrub of the operating session only and always follows the first wash of the procedure
A nail brush is not necessary for reduction of bacterial counts and can lead to skin damage and an increase in skin cell shedding When proceeding directly from one case to
another, cleaning the nails with a nail pick can be omitted
Each scrub must last three minutes.

To ensure adequate contact on the skin of the antiseptic solution. There is no evidence that more than a two-three minute wash (decontamination) using an aqueous disinfectant is required, before any “sterile” procedure is undertaken
Two sterile paper towels must be used for drying of hands and arms. They must be blotted dry.
The principle of working from fingertips to elbows must be adhered to.
This allows dirty water to run from the hands to the elbows and does not allow the reverse which would re-contaminate the hands and arms
The hands are dried first and must be dried thoroughly.
Wet surfaces transfer micro-organisms more effectively than dry surfaces.
A corkscrew action must be used to blot the arm dry from the hand to the elbow. The towel must be folded so that the drying hand is protected from contact with the arm/
The towel is discarded immediately into a black sack household waste bin
The process is repeated for the other arm
Alcohol hand rubs are acceptable to repeated hand washing; however, they are not appropriate for use when hands are visibly contaminated, as these rubs do not remove soil or debris.
These should only be applied between cases when proceeding directly from one case to another.
All gowns must conform to standard EN 13795

The EN 13795 standard is issued by European Directive and requires all gowns to be able to with stand the user performing all that is required from the surgical procedure without compromising the sterile field, and to be resistant to liquid penetration and microbial penetration, within a minimal release of particles
All gowns must be in a good state of repair and any gown not so must be discarded and returned to the manufacturer
Personnel must be aware of the specification of the gown and its suitability for the procedure to be undertaken, how it is packed,
presented, and put on and once put on what area of sterility it affords the wearer
As the gown is put on, the practitioner must ensure that they touch the inside of the gown only and that both arms are inserted into the sleeves of the gown together
The circulating person will tie the gown from the top and finish at the waist
To wrap around, the scrub person will seek the assistance of another scrub person where possible
All theatre gowns worn for clinical procedures must be disposed of at completion of procedure in line with CM32 Waste Management Policy
Surgical gloves must conform to the standard EN455 parts 1,2 and 3 and preferably be latex safe

Gloves act as a barrier to prevent transmission of infection between staff and patients and as a personal barrier. Latex safe gloves will aid in reduction of healthcare workers latex allergy and prevent complications in those patients with type 11 latex allergy
The surgical glove must fit appropriately for comfort, dexterity and sensitivity
Personnel are encouraged to double glove

Double gloving provides an extra layer of protection and reduces the number of perforations to inner gloves in all types of surgery. The decision to double glove must be made on the risk posed by the surgical procedure and not the risk posed by the patient or personal preference
The closed method of gloving is the preferred option for putting on sterile gloves

Scrubbed personnel must be aware of the area of sterility which includes. Hands and forearms Below nipple line to waist level Hands must be kept above waist level and below shoulder level and must be visible at all times

When gloves require to be changed intra-operatively due to a puncture or inadvertent contamination, the gloves must be removed in a way that avoids further contamination. It is preferable to don a second pair of gloves
At the completion of a sterile procedure, gowns, gloves, single use eye protection and masks must be treated as clinical waste and be disposed of into clinical waste bags in accordance with CM32
